00001 /*-------------------------------------------------------------------------
00002  *
00003  *   FILE
00004  *      pqxx/result.h
00005  *
00006  *   DESCRIPTION
00007  *      definitions for the pqxx::Result class and support classes.
00008  *   pqxx::Result represents the set of result tuples from a database query

00062   class PQXX_LIBEXPORT Tuple
00063   {
00064   public:
00065     typedef Tuple_size_type size_type;
00066     Tuple(const Result *r, Result::size_type i) : m_Home(r), m_Index(i) {}
00067     ~Tuple() {} // Yes Scott Meyers, you're absolutely right[1]
00068 
00069     inline Field operator[](size_type) const;                           //[t1]
00070     Field operator[](const char[]) const;                               //[t11]
00071     Field operator[](const PGSTD::string &s) const                      //[t11]
00072         { return operator[](s.c_str()); }
00073     Field at(size_type) const;                                          //[t10]
00074     Field at(const char[]) const;                                       //[t11]
00075     Field at(const PGSTD::string &s) const { return at(s.c_str()); }    //[t11]

00094   class PQXX_LIBEXPORT Field : private Tuple
00095   {
00096   public:
00097     typedef size_t size_type;
00098 
00100 
00104     Field(const Tuple &R, Tuple::size_type C) : Tuple(R), m_Col(C) {}   //[t1]
00105 
00107 
00112     const char *c_str() const {return m_Home->GetValue(m_Index,m_Col);} //[t2]
00113 
00115     inline const char *Name() const;                                    //[t11]
00116 
00118     template<typename T> bool to(T &Obj) const                          //[t1]
00119     {
00120       if (is_null())
00121         return false;
00122 
00123       try
00124       {
00125         FromString(c_str(), Obj);
00126       }
00127       catch (const PGSTD::exception &e)
00128       {
00129         throw PGSTD::runtime_error("Error reading field " + 
00130                                    PGSTD::string(Name()) +
00131                                    ": " +
00132                                    e.what());
00133       }
00134       return true;
00135     }
00136 
00138     template<typename T> bool to(T &Obj, const T &Default) const        //[t12]
00139     {
00140       const bool NotNull = to(Obj);
00141       if (!NotNull)
00142         Obj = Default;
00143       return NotNull;
00144     }
00145 
00146     bool is_null() const { return m_Home->GetIsNull(m_Index,m_Col); }   //[t12]
00147 
00148     int size() const { return m_Home->GetLength(m_Index,m_Col); }       //[t11]
00149 
00150   private:
00151 
00152     Tuple::size_type m_Col;
00153   };

00161   class PQXX_LIBEXPORT const_iterator : 
00162     public PGSTD::iterator<PGSTD::random_access_iterator_tag, 
00163                          const Tuple,
00164                          Result::size_type>, 
00165     public Tuple
00166   {
00167   public:
00168 
00175     pointer operator->()  const { return this; }                        //[t12]
00176     reference operator*() const { return *operator->(); }               //[t12]
00177 
00178     const_iterator operator++(int);                                     //[t12]
00179     const_iterator &operator++() { ++m_Index; return *this; }           //[t1]
00180     const_iterator operator--(int);                                     //[t12]
00181     const_iterator &operator--() { --m_Index; return *this; }           //[t12]
00182 
00183     const_iterator &operator+=(difference_type i)                       //[t12]
00184         { m_Index+=i; return *this; }
00185     const_iterator &operator-=(difference_type i)                       //[t12]
00186         { m_Index-=i; return *this; }
00187 
00188     bool operator==(const const_iterator &i) const                      //[t12]
00189         {return m_Index==i.m_Index;}
00190     bool operator!=(const const_iterator &i) const                      //[t12]
00191         {return m_Index!=i.m_Index;}
00192     bool operator<(const const_iterator &i) const                       //[t12]
00193          {return m_Index<i.m_Index;}
00194     bool operator<=(const const_iterator &i) const                      //[t12]
00195         {return m_Index<=i.m_Index;}
00196     bool operator>(const const_iterator &i) const                       //[t12]
00197         {return m_Index>i.m_Index;}
00198     bool operator>=(const const_iterator &i) const                      //[t12]
00199         {return m_Index>=i.m_Index;}
00200 
00201     inline const_iterator operator+(difference_type o) const;           //[t12]
00202 
00203     friend const_iterator operator+(difference_type o, 
00204                                     const_iterator i);                  //[t12]
00205 
00206     inline const_iterator operator-(difference_type o) const;           //[t12]
00207 
00208     inline difference_type operator-(const_iterator i) const;           //[t12]
00209 
00210     Result::size_type num() const { return Row(); }                     //[t1]
00211 
00212   private:
00213     friend class Result;

00275 inline Result::Field 
00276 Result::Tuple::operator[](Result::Tuple::size_type i) const 
00277 {

00281 inline Result::Tuple::size_type Result::Tuple::size() const 
00282 { 
00283   return m_Home->Columns(); 
00284 }

00286 inline const char *Result::Field::Name() const 
00287 { 
00288   return m_Home->ColumnName(m_Col); 
00289 }

00293 template<> 
00294 inline bool Result::Field::to<PGSTD::string>(PGSTD::string &Obj) const
00295 {
00296   if (is_null())
00297     return false;
00298   Obj = c_str();
00299   return true;
00300 }

00317 inline Result::const_iterator 
00318 Result::const_iterator::operator+(difference_type o) const
00319 {
00320   return const_iterator(m_Home, m_Index + o);
00321 }
00322 
00323 inline Result::const_iterator 
00324 operator+(Result::const_iterator::difference_type o, 
00325           Result::const_iterator i)
00326 {
00327   return i + o;
00328 }
00329 
00330 inline Result::const_iterator 
00331 Result::const_iterator::operator-(difference_type o) const
00332 {
00333   return const_iterator(m_Home, m_Index - o);
00334 }
00335 
00336 inline Result::const_iterator::difference_type 
00337 Result::const_iterator::operator-(const_iterator i) const
00338 { 
00339   return num()-i.num(); 
00340 }
00341 
00342 inline Result::const_iterator Result::end() const 
00343 { 
00344   return const_iterator(this, size()); 
00345 }

00368 template<typename STREAM>
00369 inline STREAM &operator<<(STREAM &S, const pqxx::Result::Field &F)      //[t46]
00370 {
00371   S << F.c_str();
00372   return S;

00376 
00377 /* 
00378 [1] Scott Meyers, in one of his essential books, "Effective C++" and "More 
00379 Effective C++", points out that it is good style to have any class containing 
00380 a member of pointer type define its own destructor--just to show that it knows
00381 what it is doing.  This helps prevent nasty memory leak / double deletion bugs
00382 typically resulting from programmers' omission to deal with such issues in
00383 their destructors.
00384 
00385 The -Weffc++ option in gcc generates warnings for noncompliance with Scott's
00386 style guidelines, and hence necessitates the definition of this destructor,\
00387 trivial as it may be.
00388 
00389 [2] IIRC Alex Stepanov, the inventor of the STL, once remarked that having
00390 this as standard behaviour for pointers would be useful in some algorithms.
00391 So even if this makes me look foolish, I would seem to be in distinguished 
00392 company.
00393 */
00394
